716573f-a.text:
Battery Place, east from West to State Streets and showing buildings on the north side of same which at this date contained numerous rookeries, the result of their proximity to Castle Garden; the immigrant landing depot. The latter is in Battery Park; which appears partially on the right. Prominent edifices are (from left to right) the Standard Oil Building; the Welles Building; the Washington Building: The United States Custom House (flag atop) and the Battery Park Building. Note at Greenwich Street the elevated station of the first elevated line in New York; this today (1937) is used as a portion of the Sixth and Ninth Ave. lines.
About 1889.
Brown Brothers.
716573f-a.folder: Battery Place & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724545f-a.text:

716571f-a.text:
Battery Place, north side, east from West Street, to Broadway, as seen from across Battery Park. On the left, appears the Whitehall Building.
February 29, 1928.
New York Edison Co.
716571f-a.folder: Battery Place & West Street, Manhattan, NY

724538f-a.text:
West Street, east side, north from Battery Park (South Ferry). Also shown is Battery Place, north side, east from and including West, to Washington Streets. Prominently shown, is the Whitehall Building (Nos. 1-14 West Street): said building consisting of 2 units, 20 and 32 stories in
height.
February 29, 1928.
New York Edison Company
724538f-a.folder: West Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY

730322f-b.title: General view - [Manhattan - Battery Place - West Street - Whitehall Building.]
730322f-b.text:
A general view northward (in No. 1) and eastward (No's 2 and 3) from the Whitehall Building at Battery Place and West Street, to show (in the first instance) the roof tops of the Syrian quarter and the office structures surrounding same. The latter are grouped around Bowling Green with the pyramidal Standard Oil Building doubly depicted. Beyond is the East River and the Borough of Brooklyn. In the background of No. 1 are the Telephone Company Building on West Street and the Woolworth and Singer Buildings on Broadway.
June 20, 1929
Views 1,2 and 3
P. L. Sperr
730322f-b.folder: Battery Place - West Street - Whitehall Building., Manhattan, NY

724541f-a.folder: West Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY

724539f-b.text:
West Street, north from Battery Place, showing an inclusive view of this marginal thoroughfare with buildings lining the easterly side of same and facing North (Hudson)River piers. To the right in View No. 1 are the Whitehall, the Downtown Athletic Club and the United Fruit Buildings. The prominent center structure is the 29 story N. Y. Telephone Building. View No. 2 shows only the pier fronts and the cars parked outside
of same.
October 18, 1939
Views: 1-2
P. L. Sperr
724539f-b.folder: West Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY

724542f-a.folder: West Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY

724543f-a.text:
A novel example of the set-back design of one building helping its neighbor---the tall downtown athletic club in the center and the thirty-one story office building known as 21 West St. at the right, showing how the office structure was enabled to enjoy southern exposure on both the Washington St. and West St. sides of the site by virtue of the adjoining club building being set back from its bullding line at the street level. Thus the office building enjoys the unique position of an isolated structure with its Washington, Morris and West St. Frontages affording it light from all four directions. The Building at the left is the Whitehall Building at Battery Place.
No date.
724543f-a.folder: West Street & Battery Place, Manhattan, NY
